{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3662593,"name":"Everett33","username":"Everett33","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/everett33/{size}/5027_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-24T16:27:19.237Z","cooked":"

After 6 seasons of mentoring 5660, our pit setup, or lack thereof, was getting tiring to both pack and load into events. After just myself and @MatthewS had to load up everything for an off-season event, we knew it was time to upgrade. Our setup took 6+ people to get everything out of the trailer and moved to our pit in one trip. Once in the pit, chargers, extension cords, batteries, and shelving all needed to be dug out of their totes, and then setup before the team could begin working on robot inspection. It was easy to forget things back at home base, and if it wasn’t in the main toolbox, finding a spare part or larger tool meant digging through multiple FIRST totes to find it. If you needed a piece of raw material you had to rip apart the bundle and hopefully find what you needed. All of this takes time and adds to the stress of loading in and competing at events.

2015-2023 Pit Setup
  • 72” Table provided by the venue
  • Harbor Freight 27” 2-piece toolbox
  • Hardware Bin Cart
  • Mini Folding Table
  • 4+ FIRST Totes
  • Air Compressor
  • Collapsable Shelf
  • Misc Loose Things
  • Robot on Cart
  • 2X folding carts for moving all loose items
  • Pile of spare raw materials usually taped together into a bundle
    20220310_1936551920×1440 284 KB

    20220319_1833481920×2560 437 KB

We sat down and looked through my 15 years of robotics photos and over 30 team’s pit setups to make a checklist of wants and needs for our own SuperPit. Our main pit structure was going to be the third generation of square tube frame SuperPit started by 973 in 2014, and improved upon by @MatthewS on 5460 in 2018. We chose this route because we could mig weld the steel (yes they are steel) frames ourselves, and this style of SuperPit would give us the best bang for our buck.

New SuperPit Requirements
  • Fit into a 102”x102” pit since Michigan is known to have some tight pits at events.
  • 24” max workbench depth for maximum robot space in the middle.
  • Fit into a 7’x14’ trailer with a 72” tall ramp door opening.
  • Not require 120v power to set up.
  • Not require any heavy lifting to set up.
  • Require minimal setup to be ready for use. This includes not needing to use any tools to set up the pit.
  • Pack up into as minimal a number of separate pieces as possible.
  • 5” diameter heavy duty casters for longevity and to make pushing across the plastic tile floor at MSC as smooth as possible.
  • A corner cart to make the sometimes not accessible corner area as useful as possible.
  • First order retrievability for as many parts and tools as possible. Aka, not having to move something to get to something else.
  • Require only 1 power outlet to supply the pit with power
  • Have overhead lighting, free use outlets, dedicated outlets, and testing tools all built into the structure, so everything is ready at the flip of a switch.
  • Have a place for phones and other small items that end up sitting out on the workbench.
  • Use a standard 46” toolbox for the main tool storage.
  • A 21” x 73” x 5” drawer for storing 72” sticks of raw materials and sheet goods.
  • A 42” TV for match live streams.
  • Delrin tube inserts and side guides on the vertical extension tubes to reduce friction
  • High quality design and build within a reasonable budget.

After at least a month of brainstorming and 3D design in SolidWorks, we were ready to melt some metal. During the design phase we had been calling vendors looking for sponsorships to help pay for or provide products for our SuperPit. We were able to get the following donated.

  • ESE LLC - Build space and use of CNC and manual machine tools
  • DCS Water Jet Cutting, Inc. - Cutting and bending sheet metal trim pieces and material drawer
  • Colson Caster - 12X 5” heavy duty casters
  • Premier Powder Coating - Black and Color Matched Gray powder coat

Over 225 man-hours were spent cutting, welding, grinding, wiring, and assembling the three main pieces. We finished 95% of the SuperPit before the kickoff of the 2024 season. During the 2024 build season we had to button up the wiring, Battery Cart assembly, and install the sheet metal trim. After our normal Saturday kickoff meeting, the majority of the team stayed longer to start organizing parts and hardware into their new home in the SuperPit. Our old pit setup fit into a single axle 6x12 trailer with a rear door and no ramp. Before we began building the SuperPit we determined that it would be easier to build a SuperPit in the off-season and then figure out a trailer later or borrow one if needed to move it to competitions during the 2024 season. We ended up using my single axle 6x10 trailer and the team’s 6x12 single axle trailer to move everything. My trailer was not rated for the fully loaded SuperPits, so we removed the battery cart and FIRST totes, and put them along with the robot and TV cart in the team’s old trailer.

SuperPit Overall
  • 4X Albion (Colson) 1050 Lb capacity Swivel Caster
    • Pit Carts 1 & 2 have 2X swivel locks for trailer loading
  • 2X 1000 Lb Weld on D-Rings for Trailer Tie Downs
  • Steel Square Tube frame Construction
  • ¼” HDPE over ¾” plywood bench top
  • ¼” HDPE rear enclosure panels
  • 14” 12v Electric actuators on Carts 1 and 2
    • Gas shocks carry majority of the weight
  • External Anderson SB50 connectors for lift actuator power
    • RV Slideout toggle switches for controlling the actuators
  • E-Stop Switches in each corner to quickly turn off all pit 120 volt functions

5660 SuperPit BOM.xlsx (27.6 KB)
BOM does not include the SuperSnack Cart
5660 SuperPit Schematics.pdf (204.6 KB)

20240327_1914441920×2560 570 KB

Toolbox Cart
  • 8X easy access outlets
  • 12 volt Anderson 1327 hookup for component benchtop testing
  • ¼” Push-Connect Pneumatic Testing Station
  • 46” Kobalt Toolbox for all high use tools
  • Removable 12 Battery cart
  • 4” Swivel Bench Vise
  • Hidden trash bin
  • High use nut and bolt hardware storage
  • High Priority spare standard parts storage
  • Notebook Cubby
  • 72” LED Bench Light
    1B1A00341920×2880 374 KB

    1B1A00651920×1280 189 KB
Drawer Cart
  • 73” x 21” x 5” drawer for spare raw materials
    • 8X Soft Close Drawer slides
    • Latching Handle
  • 2 Gallon Quiet Air Compressor
  • Mini Refrigerator
  • Incoming Power voltage display
  • Pit Power Amp draw meter
  • 4X FIRST Totes for larger spare parts and other low use items
  • 26’ x 1/4” Air Hose Reel
  • 50’ 3-Plug Cord Reel
  • 5X easy access outlets including 2X USB outlets
  • 12 volt Anderson 1327 hookup for component benchtop testing
  • Phone Shelf
  • Paper Towel Rack
  • Low Use hardware storage
  • Low Priority spare parts and tools storage
  • Match Schedule Board
  • 72” LED Bench Light
    1B1A00451920×2880 336 KB
TV Cart
  • 42” Fire TV with Twitch app
  • 600mm 12V Electric Actuator for majority of TV Lift
  • Custom 4-Bar lift for additional 14.625” of TV lift
    • 2X 2.4” 15Lb gas shocks for TV 4-Bar Lift
  • Sealed bottom main frame tubes with npt plugs for 30lb of lead shot ballast
  • Front and top doors for storage access in any pit configuration
  • TV & PC power outlet
  • HDMI cable for laptop hookup
    20231206_2127081920×2560 510 KB

    20231204_1800051920×2560 438 KB

    20250307_171032(0)1920×2560 581 KB
SuperSnack Cart

After seeing multiple teams at MSC with shelving setup in the lunch areas in 2023, and 5612 snack cart in 2024, we decided to build our own while finishing up the 2025 robot. Typically in the lunch area of a competition the cooler is on the ground taking up floor space. We built the shelving unit over the cooler to use the air space above it for storage so the table can be clear for food. This allows one person to bring a large cooler and all of the snacks to the lunch area in one trip. One benefit of being a smaller team is we can fit a competition weekend worth of snacks, plates, silverware, and cups, in a small cart like this.

  • 57” Overall Height for easy pushing through a crowded gym
  • Igloo Marine Ultra 70 Qt Cooler
    • Tall enough for 2-liter bottles to stand up
    • Opens far enough to remove 2-liter while in the cart
  • 4X Harbor Freight 5” Rubber Swivel Casters
  • ULine 18”x36” Mobile Shelving Cover shortened by 13”
  • 9X Sterilite 16 Qt Clear Snap Top Bins
  • 2x1 steel tube base and 1x1 angle iron upper structure
    20230406_1629101920×1440 186 KB

    20250201_2036401920×2560 757 KB

    SuperSnack557×851 38.3 KB

    20250610_1934441920×2560 719 KB

    20250610_1934091920×2560 620 KB

    20250610_1933271920×2560 371 KB

    69363278955099368831537×2047 462 KB
Build Photos

20230807_1151461920×2560 439 KB

20230818_1826111920×1440 209 KB

20230912_1819501920×1440 224 KB

20231121_1753021920×2560 417 KB

20231121_1752391920×1440 398 KB

20241007_1850201920×2560 789 KB

20231213_2107121920×1440 303 KB

2025 Post Season Upgrades
  • We modified how the Tote shelf was mounted to the frame to lower it by ½”. With the plywood over top of the horizontal tubes , you could not remove the top tote without sliding the lower tote part way out.
  • The aluminum tubing for the electrical was originally ⅛” x 2” square tubing. This makes it difficult to fit all of the circuits and almost impossible to fit USB outlets due to their depth. We replaced the short piece of tubing under the phone shelf with a piece of ⅛” x 2x3 tubing so we could add some USB outlets under the phone shelf.
  • The original material drawer was bent out of one piece of 20 Gauge mild steel with a hemmed top edge and bracing welded inside. We had problems with warping while welding in the bracing, which then made installing and aligning the 8X drawer slides a hassle. The fix for this was to weld a skeleton of the drawer using ½” square tubing and then rivet the sheetmetal to that before stitch welding them all into one piece. This version of the drawer is able to be opened and closed with one hand.
Building Another Team a SuperPit Frame

A Michigan team contracted myself and @MatthewS to weld them a set of SuperPit frames in September of 2024. After having built ours, we made the upgrades listed above to theirs and we were also able to build it faster using better manufacturing techniques. Total time to go from 24’ sticks of raw material to the welded frames ready for powder coat was 106 man hours.

20241004_1619321920×2560 559 KB

20241111_1707481920×1440 376 KB

20241112_1837461920×1440 365 KB

Trailer Loading & Weights

Our SuperPits are made of a welded steel 14 gauge tubing main frame, which sounds heavy, but actually isn’t that bad when you look at the final weights.

  • 7x14 Vee Nose Trailer
  • Robot Cart On Passenger SIde Vee
    • Robot Mounted to Robot Cart
  • TV Cart on Drivers Side Vee
    • Shipping Blanket protects it from the wall
  • Toolbox Cart on Drivers side
  • Drawer Cart on Passenger Side
  • SuperSnack Cart on Drivers Side
    • Shipping Blanket protects it from the wall
  • Passenger side door is not obstructed and is still usable
  • Trailer Weight - 1975 Lb
  • Toolbox Cart - 1159 Lb
  • Drawer Cart - 852 Lb
  • TV Cart - 191 Lb
  • Robot & Cart - 227 Lb
  • SuperSnack Cart - 239 Lb
    Total Weight Pulled By Tow Vehicle - 4643 Lb
    Trailer Loaded1500×2000 343 KB

    Trailer Loaded Top View1525×840 72.7 KB

After two seasons of use, there have not been any issues or “I wish we did that’s”. The only upgrade we still want to make is an overhead boom light on one or both large carts. The 6’ lights over the benches are bright, but having light directly over the robot would be ideal.

Everett
